Subject: Re: [neat] Time series framework

I have done the same thing under NEAT and rtNEAT using the C++
version. I have not been able to get particularly good results though
from it.  My scenario is below, perhaps you could compare it to yours
and tell me if how it differs.

Set of inputs e.g. close, open high, low, f(close), g(close) etc
Target output e.g. a real number indicating the optimal action and conviction.

Results:  A huge variance in results ( seems to destory good networks)
with the best only reaching 76%.
A known 96% network is a time-recurrent network with 1 hidden layer
with 2 nodes.

Do you learn over various time windows to remove specific window bias?

I have not tried variable mutation rates, but am happy to discuss
avenues for this application.

Tom

On 3/20/07, shanemcdonaldryan <shanemcdonaldryan@...> wrote:
> Hi,
>
> I am in the midst of building a times series predicting framework
> based on Matt Buckland's windows c++ code.
>
> I've removed the visualization aspects.
>
> Made it compile under windows and Linux (the same code runs 250%
> faster under Linux BTW).
>
> Made a generalized framework for loading time series patterns from a file.
>
> It is quite rough and undocumented but it allows you to simply edit a
> parameter file and present patterns to do time-series prediction using
> NEAT. I think it is also quite fast and I have some plans that I will
> elucidate on in my next message that could significantly speed it up.
>
> I've also built a little tool to run the saved result network and
> generate a CSV file. So you can load the times series as a graph in
> excel and visualize the results of your networks prediction compared
> to the original time series.
>
> It has plenty of work that needs done on it. But I figured I might
> create a Sourceforge page and post it if anyone is interested?
>
> Thanks,
>
> Shane
>
>
>
>
